question: A drug addict keeps scratching his body and complains that he feels insects creeping on his body. What is he suffering from?

A 38-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a history of end-stage renal disease secondary to hypertension. She has undergone dialysis 3 times weekly for the last 5 years and her medical records show progressive elevation of calcium levels over the last year. On physical examination, Body Mass Index (BMI) is 22.5 kg/m², blood pressure (BP) is 145/98 mmHg, and pulse rate is 91 beats/min. Laboratory test results: total calcium= 11.9 mg/dL (8.2-10 .2 mg/dL), phosphorus= 6.7 mg/dL (2.3-4.7 mg/dL), creatinine = 9.3 mg/dL (0.6-1.1 mg/dL), alkaline phosphatase = 1181 U/L (50-120 U/L). What is the most likely cause of her hypercalcemia?
A 56-year-old man was taking medications for osteoporosis secondary to hyperparathyroidism and recently was diagnosed with osteosarcoma. Which of the following medications he must be using?
A 6-year-old child presents with signs and symptoms of adrenal insufficiency. He also has a long history of mucocutaneous candidiasis. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A farmer’s wife while picking cotton from cotton pods develops nausea and dyspnea. When taken to hospital she was diagnosed with organophosphorus poisoning. What is the most likely route of entry of poison in this patient?

A man, charged with murder, pleaded insanity in a court of law. He was brought before the medical officer for examination. How will the medical officer differentiate between true and feigned insanity?

answers.option: In feigned insanity the onset is gradual
In feigned insanity fatigue does not set in
In feigned insanity the person appreciates repeated examination
In feigned insanity behavioral disturbances are uniform
In feigned insanity peculiar facial expressions are absent

question: A patient reports to the psychiatry ward with a firm belief that somebody wants to kill him. What is this type of delusion called?
An asthmatic individual who is on regular therapy for the past year develops symptoms of Cushing's syndrome. What is the most likely etiology?
An old lady living alone has locked her room door, but she keeps checking whether the door is locked or not every 5 minutes. Which of the following conditions is she most likely to be suffering from?

Students of 2nd-year MBBS are given a slide of the pancreas for study. The endocrine part shows islets of Langerhans with different types of cells. What cells of the pancreas secrete pancreatic polypeptide?
The anti-inflammatory effects of glucocorticoids are due to which fundamental mechanism?

answers.option: Inhibit leukotriene and prostaglandin synthesis via inhibition of phospholipase A2
Simulate histamine release from mast cells

question: What is the most common source of ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production?

A 13-year-old girl presented with her parents with complaints of rapid decreased in her weight. According to the parents she has also complain of tremulousness, headache, mood disturbances, behavioral swings, difficulties with sleep, decrease in attention span, hyperactivity and a decline in school performance. On examination her eyes are protruded with lid lag. Her skin is smooth and flushed with excessive sweating. She is tachycardic with increased systolic blood pressure and a widened pulse pressure. What should be the treatment of choice to treat her underlying condition?

A 14-year-old boy with type 1 diabetes is brought to the hospital complaining of dizziness. Laboratory findings show severe hypoglycemia and ketoacidosis. Which of the following drugs should be administered to achieve rapid control of severe ketoacidosis?

A 19-year-old girl is brought to the emergency room by her family who reports that she swallowed a liquid poison in a suicide attempt. On examination, she is bradycardic, hypotensive, flaccid, has excessive salivation, and has convulsions and fasciculations. What is the likely cause of poisoning?

A 21-year-old healthy male presents with history of on & off abdominal pain, recurrent bilateral kidney stones, and femur bone deformity. His blood reports show increased levels of PTH and increased blood calcium levels. After a complete workup, he is diagnosed with hyperplasia of all four parathyroid glands. Which of the following statements is best regarding his management of hyperplasia of all four glands?

answers.option: Excision of all four glands and auto-transplantation of gland or portion of gland at cubital fossa
Excision of any three parathyroid gland and leave one glands as such
Excision of all four parathyroid glands only
Excision of all four gland and leave portion of parathyroid gland at same site

question: A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with weight loss, diarrhea, and tremors for 2 months. He complains of excessive sweating and palpitations whenever he commutes to his office in the morning. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. He later suffers from Hashimoto's thyroiditis. His primary physician orders the following labs and refers him to you. TSH: 0.002 mIU/L (0.4-2). Serum T4: 23.8 ng/ml (6.5-11.5). What is the interpretation of his lab results?

A 23-year-old woman has a routine health status examination. Her body mass index is 22. Laboratory studies show fasting plasma glucose is 120 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows mild glucosuria, but no ketonuria or proteinuria. She has no detectable insulin autoantibodies. Her father was similarly affected at age 20. She is most likely to have a mutation in a gene encoding for which of the following?

A 23-year-old woman, nulliparous, tests positive for anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies and has symptoms consistent with hypothyroidism including constipation, fatigue, dry skin, and weight gain. Which of these conditions is she most likely to have?

A 23-year-old, previously healthy woman died suddenly after complaining of a mild sore throat the previous day. At autopsy, her adrenal glands are enlarged, and there are extensive bilateral cortical hemorrhages. Which of the following organisms best accounts for these findings?

A 25-year-old addict was spraying insecticide in the fields for the last three hours when he suddenly developed shortness of breath and cough. On examination he was found to have miosis, lacrimation, and salivation. What is the antidote of this poison?

A 25-year-old lactating female comes to the office with a painful swelling on her left breast for the last 5 days and fever for the last 2 days. The swelling has enlarged progressively with increasing pain. On examination, the swelling is located in the left upper quadrant, is erythematous, soft, and tender. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 25-year-old lady presents to the endocrine clinic with complaints of weight loss, excessive sweating, tachycardia, and tremors. She was diagnosed with hyperthyroidism after some laboratory investigations. What is the most appropriate cause of tremors in this patient?

A 25-year-old man was traveling by train when he was offered a samosa with a cup of tea by a fellow passenger. After an hour he became aggressive and started talking irrelevantly and picking thread from his clothes. On examination, he was found to have dilated pupils, dysarthria, dry hot skin, and drunken gait. What is the poison responsible for this man's presentation?

A 26-year-old woman is complaining of an abnormal tingling sensation in her hands and feet. For the last 2 years, a neurologist is treating her for a seizure disorder. On examination, her blood pressure (BP) is 125/77 mmHg and her pulse is 98 beats/min. Her investigations show: calcium = 6.5 (7.5-8.5 mg/dL), phosphate = 4.8 (2.5-4.0 mg/dL). What is the most likely cause of her hypocalcemia?

A 27-year-old female undergoes total thyroidectomy for multinodular goiter. During this operation, the inferior thyroid artery is ligated. Which of the following nerves is intimately related to this artery?

A 27-year-old woman experienced sudden severe abdominal pain. On physical examination, she had marked abdominal tenderness and guarding. Laboratory studies showed serum glucose, 76 mg/dL; calcium, 12.2 mg/dL, and parathyroid hormone, 62 pg/mL (normal range 9 to 60 pg/mL). During surgery, four enlarged parathyroid glands were found and excised, with reimplantation of one-half of one gland. After the surgery, her serum calcium concentration returned to normal. Three years later, she had an episode of upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Abdominal MRI indicated multiple 1- to 2-cm mass lesions in the pancreas. Two years later, she now has galactorrhea. Which of the following lesions is now most likely to be present?

answers.option: Small-cell anaplastic carcinoma of the lung

question: A 28-year-old woman presents to the endocrine clinic with secondary amenorrhea and galactorrhoea for the last 6 months. Her general physical and systemic examination is normal. Lab investigations reveal, prolactin = 3250 mU/L (60–620), free T4 = 15.5 pmol/L (11.5–22.7), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) = 2.5 mU/L (0.35–5.5), and urine pregnancy test is negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 29-year-old female has a TSH of 13.5 mlU/L (normal: 0.5 to 4.7 mlU/L). Which of the following agents is most appropriate to treat this TSH abnormality?

A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with palpitations, weight loss, and excessive sweating for almost 5-6 months. She cannot concentrate on carrying out her daily activities especially looking after her children. Recently, she also developed pain in both eyes and her friend told her that one of her eyes has become more prominent than the other. What is the most likely cause of her condition?

A 33-year-old woman presents with a lump in front of her neck. She is also giving history of on & off abdominal pain, and recurrent bilateral kidney stones. On examination, the size of lump is 2 x 2 cm. After complete investigations, she is diagnosed having parathyroid adenoma in one of parathyroid glands. Which of the following statements is correct regarding her management of primary hyperparathyroidism secondary to parathyroid adenoma?

answers.option: Excision and auto-transplantation gland in posterior triangle of neck
Excision of parathyroid adenoma gland only
Excision and auto-transplantation of gland at cubital fossa
Excision and auto-transplantation of one gland in popliteal fossa

question: A 35-year-old lady is diagnosed with autoimmune hypothyroidism. Her physician was concerned about thyroid auto-antibodies. Which of the following is the most appropriate antibody to detect the autoimmune thyroid disease?

A 35-year-old lady presents with complaints of heat intolerance, weight loss, and swelling in front of the neck. She is also found to have bilaterally protruded eyes. What is the most appropriate terminology used for the protruded eyes in this patient?

A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of feeling of fullness in her neck but has no other complaints. The enlargement has been gradual and painless for more than 1 year. Physical examination confirms diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland without any apparent masses. Laboratory studies of thyroid function show a normal free T4 level and a slightly increased TSH level. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
A 35-year-old woman undergoes a successful thyroidectomy but develops neck swelling and dyspnea soon after the surgery. What is the next best step in management?

answers.option: Urgent transfer to the operating theatre

question: A 40-year-old female with occasional complaints of dysuria and polyuria, presents with body aches and fatigue and the following labs: PTH 103 pg/ml (10-65), Ca 8.2 mg/dl (8.5-10.0), Phosphate 4.0 mmol/L (2.5-5.0), Albumin 4.4 mg/dl (2.5-5.5), Alkaline phosphatase 243 mg/dl (< 125), Vitamin D 8.0 ng/mL (> 30), 1,25 hydroxyvitamin D 7.0 pg/ml (18-78). What is the most likely cause of her condition?

A 40-year-old woman notices that her gloves from the previous winter do not fit her hands. Her friends remark that her facial features have changed in the past year and that her voice seems deeper. On physical examination, she is afebrile. Her blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. She has coarse facial features. Examination of the foot shows an increased amount of soft tissue beneath the calcaneus. Which of the following statements is most appropriate for her condition?

A 40-year-old woman presents with an increasing feeling of fullness in her neck for the past 7 months. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is enlarged and nodular. A fine needle aspiration biopsy of the thyroid is done, and she undergoes thyroidectomy. Gross examination of the thyroid shows a multicentric thyroid neoplasm; microscopically, the neoplasm is composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped cells forming nests and trabeculae. There is a prominent, pink hyaline stroma. Which of the following immunohistochemical stains is most likely to be useful in the diagnosis of this neoplasm?

A 42-year-old man presents with polyuria and polydipsia for the past 4 months. On physical examination, there are no specific findings. Laboratory findings include serum Na+ 155 mol/L (high); K+ 3.9 mol/L; Cl- 111 mmol/L; CO2 27 mmol/L; glucose 84 mg/dL; creatinine 1 mg/dL. The specific gravity of urine is 1.002 (low). Which of the following is most likely to be deficient in this patient?

A 44-year-old man sees his physician because of a ''lump'' on the left side of his neck. Physical examination shows a non-tender nodule on the left lobe of the thyroid gland. A cervical node is also enlarged and non-tender. Laboratory studies show no thyroid autoantibodies in his serum, and the T4 and TSH levels are normal. A thyroidectomy is performed. High-power microscopic examination of the thyroid shows Orphan Annie eye nuclei, nuclear grooves, and psammoma bodies. Which of the following is most likely to contribute to the development of the thyroid nodule in this patient?
A 45-year-old female presented with a nodule in her thyroid region. What is the most common thyroid carcinoma in this age group?

A 54-year-old, married woman para-2 comes to the clinic with the complaint of weight gain and lethargy for the past 3 months. She had her last menstrual period 6 years back. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, her pulse is 65/min, and is regular bilaterally. Her body mass index (BMI) falls in the obese range. Her eyes are puffy, she complains of breathlessness, and cold intolerance, her skin is coarse and her abdomen has white striations present. What is the best diagnostic test for this woman?

answers.option: Oral glucose tolerance test and TSH

question: A 56-year-old female patient who has a history of diabetes and hypertension starts taking amiodarone after her coronary artery bypass surgery. Later, she presents with symptoms of tiredness, sensitivity to cold, weight gain, and constipation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old female with multinodular goiter is scheduled for a near total thyroidectomy. Which of the drugs will be administered for 10-14 days before surgery to reduce the vascularity of her thyroid gland?

A 60-year-old male presents with end-stage renal disease, hyperkalemia, and metabolic acidosis. He also has hyperparathyroidism as a physiological response to hypocalcemia. What is the patient suffering from?

A 62-year-old man has been concerned about a gradual weight gain over the past 30 years. He is 174 cm (5 ft 7 inches) tall and weighs 91 kg (body mass index 30 kg/m²). He is taking no medications. On physical examination, he has decreased sensation to pinprick and light touch over the lower extremities. Patellar reflexes are reduced. Motor strength seems to be normal in all extremities. Laboratory studies show glucose of 269 mg/dL, creatinine of 1.9 mg/dL, total cholesterol of 220 mg/dL, HDL cholesterol of 27 mg/dL, and triglycerides of 261 mg/dL. A chest radiograph shows mild cardiomegaly. Five years later, he has claudication in the lower extremities when he exercises. Based on these findings, which of the following complications in lower limbs can occur in this patient?

A 66-year-old woman is complaining of abdominal pain, constipation and polyuria. In the past, she underwent renal stone surgery. On examination, her blood pressure is 145/77mmHg and pulse is 98/min. Her fasting glucose and kidney function are normal but her calcium is found to be elevated at 13.05 mg/dL (NR 8.5-11.0). What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?

A 66-year-old woman is complaining of abdominal pain, constipation. In the past, she underwent renal stone surgery. On examination, her blood pressure (BP) is 145/77 mmHg and her pulse is 98 beats/min. Her fasting glucose and kidney function tests are normal but her calcium is found to be elevated at 13.05 mg/dL. What is the most likely cause of her hypercalcemia?

A 7-year-old boy comes to the clinic for evaluation of short stature. He is shorter than his peers. His bone age is 4 years and his height is equivalent to that in a 5-year-old child(3rd percentile). No chronic diseases run in the family. Laboratory investigations reveal no abnormal findings. What is the most likely reason for his short stature?

A 7-year-old kid presents to the outpatient department with a protruding tongue, mental retardation, umbilical hernia, and coarse facial features. He is diagnosed with cretinism. A deficiency of which hormone can cause this?

A 73-year-old woman presents with complaints of fatigue, sluggishness, weight gain, cold intolerance, dry skin, and muscle weakness for the last 2 months. When initiating T4 therapy for an elderly patient with long-standing hypothyroidism, small doses are administered in the beginning. This is done to avoid which of the following?

A child is brought to the emergency department with a history of ‘alleged’ snake bite. There is no swelling and no bite mark is seen on examination. He is anxious, has dyspnea, and is unable to open his eyes. The blood clotting mechanism observed for 20 minutes is normal. Which of the following is the best initial step in management?

answers.option: Give anxiolytic and reassure the patient
Give anti snake venom (ASV) and neostigmine
Do not give anti snake venom (ASV) and observe the patient
Give anti snake venom (ASV) and observe the patient

question: A false belief that a person has which cannot be corrected is called?

A male patient of 50 years of age was diagnosed as a case of hyperthyroidism. The treating physician suggested him an anti-thyroid drug. Which of the following drugs inhibits the organification step of thyroid hormone synthesis?

A male was caught red-handed while robbing a chemical store at Jodia bazaar. A mob was gathered and started brutal violence against the robber. One of the men bought a chemical from the nearby store and forced the robber to drink it. The helpless person did as directed, and after a few minutes developed severe convulsions, cyanosis, and dyspnea. Blood-stained froth could be seen in his mouth. What is the most likely cause of poisoning?

A man is brought to the district hospital after being bitten by a snake on foot. He complained of localized pain and swelling of the foot. He then started bleeding through his mouth and nose. On examination, petechial hemorrhage could be seen under his skin. He got bitten by which type of snake?

A middle-aged man always remains dirty. He always complains about hearing some voices saying Mr. ABC is against you. What is the false perception of something in the absence of an external stimuli called?

A patient presents with weakness, easy fatigability, gastrointestinal disturbances, and hyperpigmentation. Features are suggestive of adrenal insufficiency. What should be the time of sample collection for adrenal insufficiency?
A person diagnosed with type 1 diabetes mellitus develops ketoacidosis. What is the first step in management?
A woman taking corticosteroids for chronic interstitial lung disease (ILD) develops moon facies and weakness. Her lung functions have improved over time. What is the most appropriate management?
A young boy is brought to the hospital in a state of shock and fright after being bitten by a cobra on hand. What is the next step of management after reassuring the patient?

answers.option: Wash the wound with soap and water

question: A young male patient is suffering from a delusional belief where he imagines that he is going to be poisoned by his relatives, wife, and son and they will rob his property. What is this type of delusion called?

A young patient comes to the emergency room (ER) with intense thirst and dehydration, a blood sugar of 608 mg/dl, serum osmolarity of 300 mOsmol/kg, and pH of 7.1. He is breathing rapidly and his breath emits a fruity smell. What is the diagnosis based on these findings?
Absorbed poison can be removed by?
Amine hormones are synthesized from which precursor?

An 11-year-old girl has a short stature and increased weight. She also complains of cold intolerance and increased sleep. Her bone age is delayed. Lab results show an increased level of TSH and a reduced free T4. What is the most likely diagnosis?
An 8-year-old child presents to the clinic with short stature. A growth hormone deficiency is suspected. Which of the following lab values is the most appropriate test to perform in this child?

An infant presents to the outpatient department with complaints of lethargy, difficulty in feeding, and constipation for the past 1 month. On examination, the baby has a protruded tongue, husky cry, and an umbilical hernia. Laboratory results show an increased level of TSH and reduced levels of free T4. What is the most likely diagnosis?
During embryogenesis of the pituitary gland, Rathke's pouch will lead to the formation of which of the following structures of the pituitary gland?
Excessive growth hormone release in adults leads to which condition?
High calcitonin levels with a nest of polygonal cells and amyloid deposits on cytology is seen in which of the following?
Hürthle cell variant is seen in which of the following?
Osteoporosis is a major adverse effect caused by glucocorticoids. Which of the following correctly explains this?
Strychnine is known to hyper-stimulate the motor nervous system in the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord. What is the mechanism of action of strychnine?

answers.option: Blocks glycine uptake at neuromuscular junction

question: Sulfonylureas are a drug of choice for which of the following?
The histological section of neurohypophysis shows supporting cells and axons with dilated terminal ends. What are the supporting cells and dilated terminal ends of axons called?
The poisoning caused by which of the following substances presents with gastrointestinal irritation, black-colored urine, and loin pain?

This medication is used to treat hyperparathyroidism in patients with chronic renal failure. It works by mimicking the role of calcium in the blood and tricks the parathyroid gland into stopping the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Which of the following medications matches with this description?
Thyroid hormone preparations like levothyroxine act on which of the following receptors?
To differentiate between true and feigned insanity, a medical officer will notice that a truly insane patient:

answers.option: Has facial expressions that do not match with emotions

question: What is the insulin preparation of choice in diabetic ketoacidosis?
What is the marked macrovascular complication of type 2 diabetes mellitus?
What is the mechanism of action of methimazole?

answers.option: Prevent binding of iodine to thyroglobulin

question: What is the mechanism of action of propylthiouracil (PTU)?
What is the most common side effect of biosynthetic growth hormone?
Where is the pituitary gland present relative to the optic chiasm?
Which drug causes a decrease in insulin resistance by upregulating peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor gamma (PPAR-γ)?
Which drug increases insulin sensitivity by increasing peripheral receptors for insulin?
Which of the following changes is made to the dosage of levothyroxine for a pregnant woman in her 2nd trimester?
Which of the following hormones does not use cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) as a second messenger?
Which of the following hormones is secreted in large quantities from the zona fasciculata of the adrenal gland?
Which of the following insulin analogs is a long-acting preparation?
Which of the following is the effect of propylthiouracil on thyroid hormone?

answers.option: Inhibits oxidation of iodide and coupling of iodine

question: Which of the following is the most common side effect of insulin therapy in type 1 diabetic patients?
Which of the following is true regarding the effect of radioiodine on the thyroid parenchyma?

answers.option: Alpha particles destroy the follicular cells
Gamma radiation destroys the parafollicular cells
Radioiodine has no effect on the thyroid parenchyma
Both alpha particles and gamma rays destroy the parafollicular cells
Beta radiations mainly destroy the follicular cell

question: Which of the following secretes androgens?
Which of these is false regarding the pituitary gland?

answers.option: Anterior pituitary is also called the adenohypophysis
It lies in fossa of the zygomatic bone
Adrenocorticotrophic hormone is released by anterior pituitary
Oxytocin and antidiuretic hormone are released by the posterior pituitary

question: Which part of the anterior pituitary secretes most of the hormones?
Which snake venom causes rhabdomyolysis?
Which type of hyperparathyroidism is a physiological response of the parathyroid gland to hypocalcemia?
Why is dexamethasone preferred in cerebral edema?

answers.option: It does not retain much sodium and water

question: 100 cancer patients were divided into two groups. One group was given chemotherapy while the other was given medications plus chemotherapy. This is an example of which of the following types of research?
24-year-old primigravida presents to the clinic with anemia and lethargy. Her mother had a thyroid disorder. She is advised thyroid profile. Which of the following levels will be checked?

answers.option: Serum TSH, free T3, free T4

question: 40-year-old presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of neck swelling for the past month. Her biopsy results show rapidly dividing follicular cells with optically clear nuclei, intracellular inclusions, and concentric calcifications. The patient is suffering from which of the following?

A 12-year-old child is diagnosed with candidiasis. His past medical history is significant for Addison's disease, hypoparathyroidism, and hypocalcemia. Which of the following conditions does the patient have?

A 12-year-old child presents with lethargy, constipation, and pain in calf for 3 months. On examination, he has protruded abdomen and coarse facial skin. Which is the single best investigation to confirm the diagnosis?
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department in an unconscious state. On examination, dehydration signs and fruity breath is observed. What is the diagnosis?

A 13-year-old girl comes to the outpatient department (OPD) with complaints of increased sweating, weight loss, and an increased appetite for 3 months. There is also a history of intermittent diarrhea for the last 3 months. On examination, she is afebrile, heart rate 130 beats/min, and respiratory rate 24 breaths/min. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 15-year-old boy presents to the outpatient department with backache, moon face, muscle weakness, and truncal obesity. On examination, the child has elevated blood pressure and delayed reflexes. The laboratory results show increased cortisol levels. Which of the following hormones would be increased in the patient?

A 15-year-old boy with diabetes Melllitus type-1 was brought to the emergency department complaining of dizziness. Laboratory reports show severe hypoglycemia and ketoacidosis. Which of the following substances can be administered to achieve rapid control of severe ketoacidosis?

A 16-year-old female came to the outpatient department with a painless swelling at her left breast which she noticed 6 months back. Upon examination, the lump is non-tender, and firm, at the 9 o'clock position, and is 3x2 cm. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 16-year-old girl presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of severe acne, oily skin, excessive body hair, and primary amenorrhea. She also has an enlarged clitoris. Which of the following tests is not useful in making the diagnosis?
A 16-year-old male is diagnosed with type 1 diabetes. He is kept on insulin for the future. Insulin deficiency is associated with which of the following?

A 17-year-old boy is admitted to the intensive care unit with complaints of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He was diagnosed with a hormonal deficiency by his primary physician and instructed to remain on hydrocortisone pills for his whole life. Unfortunately, due to the recent COVID-19 pandemic, he could not get his adequate supply and stopped taking the pills for almost 15 days. What is his current diagnosis?

A 20-day-old baby is brought to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) with complaints of vomiting for 2 days. On examination, the baby is severely dehydrated, heart rate is 165 beats/min, respiratory rate is 68 breaths/min, and the temperature is 98 F. Arterial blood gases (ABGs) reveal severe metabolic acidosis, Na = 120 mEq/L, K = 5.8 mEq/L, urea = 62 mg/dL, Cr = 1.0 mg/dL, and random blood sugar (RBS) = 30 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 20-year-old male presents with fever, fatigue, and an enlarged thyroid gland that is tender to palpation. He recovers completely in about a week. What is the most likely diagnosis?
A 20-year-old male presents with fever, fatigue, and an enlarged, tender thyroid gland. He recovers completely in about a week. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old nurse comes to the outpatient department with complaints of hyperactivity, mood swings, difficulty sleeping, diarrhea, and increased sensitivity to heat. She also complains of muscle weakness and feels tired all the time. The doctor orders a 24-hour I-131 uptake test and it shows an iodine uptake of 1.7%, which is below the normal range of 7.5% to 25%. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, diarrhea, fever, and chills after she consumed a raw beef dish at a restaurant that she had last night. She had the meal nearly sixteen hours ago and has been experiencing abdominal discomfort since. What organism is most likely to be responsible for her condition?

A 20-year-old woman is referred to the endocrinology clinic after a history of persistent headaches over the last 1 year. Her examination shows evidence of a left temporal visual field defect. Subsequent anterior pituitary functions tests confirm secondary hypothyroidism and hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. MRI of the pituitary shows a 4 × 2 cm cystic calcified parasellar lesion, which is compressing the optic chiasm. The cyst is radiologically described as showing the appearance of engine oil. Which one of the following is the likely diagnosis based on her clinical profile?

A 22-year-old female girl came to the outpatient department with complaints of fatigue, reduced stamina, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss in the last three months. On examination, there is an increased pigmentation on palmer creases. What is the most likely abnormality present in this patient?

A 22-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of weight loss, diarrhea, and tremors for the past 2 months. He also complains of excessive sweating and palpitations during his commute to his office in the morning. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day. His sister suffers from Hashimoto thyroiditis. His primary physician orders certain laboratory tests. The results are: thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) = 0.002 mIU/L (0.4-4.2), and serum T4 = 23.8 ng/mL (5.5-11.5). What is the interpretation of his laboratory results?

A 23-year-old woman with asthma started the therapy with budesonide, an inhaled steroid. The topical administration and short half-life greatly reduce the risk of systemic side effects compared with oral prednisone. The long-term daily administration of the therapeutic doses of prednisone results in which of the following?

answers.option: Increased male pattern hair growth in women
Hyperplasia of cells in zona fasciculata and reticularis of adrenal cortex

question: A 24-year-old woman comes into the outpatient department with complaints of weight gain, muscle weakness, thin arms and legs, increased fat around the base of the neck, and easy bruising in the last six months. She has also developed abdominal striae. What is the cause of her condition?

A 25-year-old female comes to the outpatient department with a complaint of inability to tolerate heat. She says she experiences excessive sweats and drastic weight loss. The physician found signs and symptoms of thyrotoxicosis and diagnosed it as primary hyperthyroidism. Which of the following accurately describes the lab findings in this patient?

answers.option: No change in the levels of TSH, T3 and T4
Low TSH, high T3 and T4

question: A 25-year-old lady is found to be tachycardic during her pre-employment checkup. Further examination reveals a 3 x 3 cm non-tender swelling on the right side of the neck, which is moving on deglutition. Her thyroid profile was subsequently requested, which revealed thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) < 0.004 mIU/L (N~ 0.5-5) and free T3: 35 pmol/L (range 10.3-24.0pmol/L). What would be the most appropriate next investigation in this patient?

A 25-year-old male came to the outpatient department (OPD) with complaints of intermittent headache and nausea for 4 months. On eye examination, he had impaired vision and diplopia. Laboratory investigations showed a decreased level of thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), and increased levels of prolactin. What is the most appropriate diagnosis for this patient?

A 25-year-old woman ended up in the emergency department with fever, palpitations, excessive sweating, vomiting, and diarrhea. On investigation, her T3, and T4 was found to be significantly raised. A diagnosis of thyroid storm was made. This condition is associated with which of the following?

A 25-year-old woman has noted breast secretions for the past month. She is not breastfeeding and has never been pregnant. She has not menstruated for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no abnormal findings. MRI of the brain shows a 0.7-cm mass in the adenohypophysis. Which of the following additional complications is most likely to be present in this patient?

A 26-year-old female presents with weight gain, fatigue, and cold intolerance. On examination, she has dry skin and bradycardia. Her TSH is 22 mu/L and her free T4 is 0.65. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 26-year-old male patient with a history of depression complained of abdominal pain for the last 4 months, an account of 4 Kg weight loss, and the patient feels light headiness on walking. There is a history of abdominal tuberculosis for which he completed the treatment. On examination, the patient is anemic and their blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg. Lab results showed serum sodium of 129 mg/dl, potassium of 4.9 mg/dl, and creatinine of 1.0 mg/dl. What is the most likely investigation to confirm this diagnosis?

A 26-year-old woman is complaining of abnormal tingling sensation in her hands and feet. For the last 2 years, a neurologist has been treating her for seizure disorder. On, examination, her blood pressure is 125/77mmHg and pulse is 98/min. Her investigations show: Calcium= 6.5 (7.5-8.5 mg/dl) Phosphate = 4.8 (2.5-4.0 mg/dl). What investigation will you do?

A 27-year-old woman has been unwell for a few days and has not been drinking or eating. She now feels better but has developed hypoglycemia and ketones are detected in her urine. What is the best management plan?

answers.option: Administer IV dextrose and send the patient home
Admit the patient and administer IV dextrose with frequent monitoring
Administer IV saline and admit the patient
Give IV insulin and admit the patient
Just monitor the patient for a while and send home later

question: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a severe headache and vision problems over the last 6 months. Head computed tomography (CT) reveals a large sellar mass extending to the suprasellar region and distorting the optic chiasm. He also describes reduced libido and sexual dysfunction for the last 1 year. On physical examination, he appears healthy and vitally stable. Findings on neurologic examination are normal, except for bitemporal hemianopsia. Laboratory test results (blood drawn at 8 am): TSH = 1.0 miU/L (0.4-4.0), FT4 = 0.9 ng/dL (0.86-1.76), cortisol = 18.0 ug/dL (5-25), prolactin = 1280 ng/mL (19-23), growth hormone (GH) = 0.5 ng/mL. (2-5) What is the most likely cause of his sellar mass?

A 28-year-old woman presents to the endocrine clinic with secondary amenorrhea and galactorrhoea for the last 6 months. Her general physical and systemic examination is normal. Lab investigations reveal: prolactin = 3250 mU/L (60–620), free T4 = 15.5 pmol/L (11.5–22.7), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) = 2.5 mU/L (0.35–5.5), and urine pregnancy test is negative. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the pituitary gland confirms the presence of a microadenoma. She is very keen to start a family in the near future and has sought advice regarding further management. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapeutic option in her case?

A 29-year-old patient comes with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, her throat is congested and her thyroid is palpable. Labs reveal that TSH is 6.8 mmol/dL and T4 and T3 are normal but at the lower end of the reference range. What is the possible diagnosis?

A 29-year-old patient comes with complaints of fever and sore throat. On examination, her throat is congested and her thyroid is palpable. She has no signs and symptoms of thyroid disease and neither has a positive family history. Labs reveal low TSH and T3 levels while her T4 is raised. What is the possible diagnosis?

A 29-year-old primigravida with no prenatal care comes to the emergency department with vaginal bleeding after the onset of labor at 38 weeks, C-section for a lacerated low-lying placenta was performed. She remained hypotensive post-operatively for about 6 hours and was transfused with 12 units of packed RBCs. Now she is unable to feed her newborn and a normal menstrual cycle was not restored. Laboratory findings are hyponatremia, hypokalemia, and hypoglycemia. Which of the following pathological lesion is she most likely to have?

A 30-year-old female comes to the clinic with the complaint of painless swelling on the left side of the neck for 3 months. Detailed history and examination reveal she has palpitations, heat intolerance, sweating, and frequent diarrhea. Her pulse is 110 beats/min, blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Her palms are moist but no tremors are observed. There is about 4 x 4 cm, soft, non-tender, swelling on the left side of the neck, which is moving upon deglutition. She has decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with increased free T3 and T4 levels. What is the most likely clinical diagnosis in this patient?

A 30-year-old female comes to the clinic with the complaint of painless swelling on the left side of the neck for 3 months. Detailed history and examination reveal she has palpitations, heat intolerance, sweating, and frequent diarrhea. Her pulse is 110 beats/min, blood pressure is 110/80 mmHg. Her palms are moist but no tremors are observed. There is about 4 x 4 cm, soft, non-tender, swelling present in the right lobe and isthmus, which is moving upon deglutition. Radioiodine shows homogenous uptake. She has decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels with increased free T3 and T4 levels. What is the best treatment option for this case?

A 30-year-old female patient, obese, nondiabetic, presented with significant weight gain, easy fatiguability, and lethargy. On examination, she looked pale, obese, and slightly confused. Her blood pressure is 170/90 mmHg, and her pulse rate is 55 beats/min. She was unable to stand from a sitting position without support and her deep tendon reflexes were diminished. With the given scenario, what is the probable diagnosis?

A 30-year-old male presents to the clinic with neck swelling and a history of weight loss of 5 kg over a month. On examination, exophthalmos, diffuse thyroid swelling, and non-pitting edema over the legs. His laboratory results show elevated T4 and decreased TSH. What will be seen in his thyroid biopsy?

answers.option: Lymphoid follicles with germinal centers and Hurtle cells
Follicular cell hyperplasia and scalloping of colloid
Diffuse fibrous deposition between atrophic follicles
Multiple hyperplastic nodules and compressed thyroid at periphery

question: A 30-year-old man presents with confusion, nausea, and vomiting. Serum electrolytes reveal a sodium level of 110 mEq/L. Serum osmolality is 250 mOsm/kg and urine osmolality is 500 mOsm/kg. If the urinary sodium is increased in this patient, what is the most likely diagnosis?

answers.option: Syndrome of inappropriate secretion of ADH (SIADH)

question: A 30-year-old woman complains of increased weight gain, fatiguability, depression, and poor memory for the past 3 months. She has pale dry skin and raised blood pressure. What is the most common investigation that will be advised?

A 30-year-old woman complains of increasing weight gain, fatigability, depression and poor memory for last three months. She is noticed to have a pale complexion, dry scaly skin and high blood pressure. What is the most important investigation you will advise?

A 30-year-old woman has been complaining of increasing weight gain, fatigability, depression, and poor memory for the last three months. She was noticed to have a pale complexion, dry scaly skin, and high blood pressure. What is the most important investigation you will advise? The given explanation best corresponds to which one of the following?

A 30-year-old woman presents to the outpatient clinic with palpitations, weight loss and excessive sweating for almost 5-6 months. She cannot concentrate on carrying out her daily activities especially looking after her children. Recently, she has also developed pain in both eyes and her friend told her that one of her eyes has become more prominent than the other. What is the most likely cause of her condition?

A 30-year-old woman was diagnosed with a case of hyperthyroidism due to graves disease. She looks healthy otherwise. In graves disease, the common cause of hyperthyroidism is the production of an antibody that causes which of the following?

answers.option: Stimulates pituitary thyrotropin releasing hormone and stimulates TSH release
Activates thyroid hormone receptors in peripheral tissues
Bind to thyroid gland thyroglobuline and increases the release of T3 and T4

question: A 31-year-old female develops shortness of breath. On examination, she is observed to have a raised jugular venous pulse (JVP) and muffled heart sounds. She has a history of hypothyroidism. Which of the following is the likely reason for the new findings?

A 32-year-old lady presents to the clinic with an inability to lactate and amenorrhea for the last 9-10 months. She delivered a baby boy almost 10 months back, during which she experienced a lot of blood loss requiring blood transfusion. She also complains of lethargy, fatigue, and is unable to take care of her baby adequately. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 32-year-old man was diagnosed with type 1 diabetes mellitus (DM) 5 years ago and was previously well controlled on insulin glargine and insulin lispro. He attended the endocrine clinic after a year, with a recent deterioration of his blood sugar levels. He complained of excessive sweating, weight gain, headaches, and decreased libido. He had to buy new pair of shoes 3 times over the last year because they became too small very soon. On examination, he has acanthosis, and there are a number of skin tags around his neck. Apart from diabetes evaluation, what single investigation is useful to assess his recent symptoms?

A 32-year-old woman presents with features of Cushing's syndrome and increased urinary cortisol levels. In a follow-up 2 weeks later, her symptoms disappeared and the cortisol levels were back to normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 33-year-old mother of two children comes with a history of amenorrhea for 6 months. She is negative about pregnancy. For some days she is also experiencing increased milk production from her breasts along with a persistent headache. She also complains of visual disturbances. An optometrist finds her lateral vision reduced. On examination, she is afebrile and nonhypertensive. Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

A 33-year-old woman presents to the endocrine clinic with weight gain, easy bruisability, and fatigue during the 3rd trimester of her pregnancy. On examination, she has high blood pressure and stria on the lower abdomen. Further blood investigations show impaired glucose tolerance on an oral glucose tolerance test. Clinical suspicion of Cushing syndrome is raised and she undergoes further evaluation. Which one of the following physiological changes is seen in the adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) cortisol axis during normal pregnancy?

answers.option: Urinary free cortisol levels up to five times the normal (non-pregnancy range)
Blunting of cortisol response to dexamethasone suppression test
Loss of diurnal rhythm of cortisol secretion

question: A 34-year-old female presents with a complaint of neck swelling for the past 6 months which has slightly increased in size. She has a history of weight gain. On clinical examination, her pulse is 80 beats/min, her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, and she is afebrile. Her neck examination reveals diffuse but non-tender swelling which moves on deglutition. Thyroid function test shows TSH = 3.0 mIU/L, Free T4 = 0.8 ng/dL. What would be the most appropriate initial investigation in this patient?

A 34-year-old man receiving medication for hyperthyroidism has a rash, pruritus, fever, diarrhea, bitter taste in his mouth, and feelings of anxiety. Which of the following drugs is most likely causing these symptoms?

A 34-year-old woman presents with a painless swelling on the left side of her neck for the past 3 months. According to her, it has increased only slightly in size. Her pulse is 90 beats/min, BP is 110/70 mmHg, the temperature is 99 degrees Fahrenheit. On examination, the swelling moves on deglutition. What is the most appropriate initial investigation in this patient?

A 35-year-old female come to the outpatient department with complaints of painless neck swelling, which she noticed 3 months back. On examination, it is found to be a 2 x 2 cm, soft, rounded, and non-tender swelling in the central neck, which is moving on deglutition but not on tongue protrusion. What is the most likely clinical diagnosis in this patient?

A 35-year-old female patient has a history of headaches with vomiting, vision disturbance, and galactorrhea. On examination, she has a loss of peripheral vision in both eyes. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of vertigo, severe weakness, and bradycardia. On taking history, she had an assisted vaginal delivery 1 month back and hospitalization of 1 week postpartum. What is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

A 35-year-old lady presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of an increase in appetite, weight loss and sweating for the past 3 months. She has a gritty sensation in her eyes. On examination, her hands are moist and warm. The thyroid gland is palpable with a bruit. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 35-year-old lady presented to the outpatient department with the complaint of an increase in appetite, weight loss, and sweating for the past 3 months. She has a gritty sensation in her eyes. On examination, her hands are moist and warm. The thyroid gland is palpable with a bruit. Which of the following is not a treatment option in this case?

A 35-year-old man comes to the outpatient department with complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, nausea, and pain in the right upper abdomen. He is a known case of hypothyroidism. He has raised jugular venous pressure, fast breathing, and increased heart rate. What is the most probable diagnosis for his condition?

A 35-year-old woman presents with a serum calcium level of 15.2 mg/dL and an elevated parathyroid hormone level. Following correction of the patient’s hypercalcemia with hydration and furosemide, which of the following is the best therapeutic approach?

answers.option: Neck exploration and resection of all 4 parathyroid glands
Neck exploration and resection of a parathyroid adenoma
Avoidance of sunlight, vitamin D, and calcium-containing dairy products

question: A 35-year-old, mother of two children, comes to the clinic with a history of amenorrhea for 6 months and headaches for 3 months, For some days she is also experiencing increased milk production from her breasts. She has concerns about her vision as she recently escaped an accident while overtaking a school bus while changing lanes. On examination she is not pregnant, her blood pressure is normal and she is afebrile. On optometric examination her lateral vision was found to be reduced. Which of the following lab test findings is most likely to be present in this woman?

A 36-year-old female presents to the clinic with complaints of secondary amenorrhea and headache for 6 months. She has 3 children, the last-born is 2 years old. She has also noted weight gain during the same time period. On examination, there is mild hirsutism, secondary sexual characteristics were well developed and there is expressive galactorrhea. However, visual confrontation shows left inferior temporal field defects. Serum thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 2.4 (0.4-4.0), luteinizing hormone (LH) is 0.2 (1.2-4.0), follicular stimulating hormone (FSH) is 2.0 (2.0-8.0) and prolactin levels are 90 (10-23). What is the possible cause of her presentation?

A 36-year-old woman was incidentally detected to have a 6 mm pituitary microadenoma on computed tomography (CT) scan of the head, performed to evaluate the causes for her recurrent headaches. Apart from the headaches that she had suffered for the last 6 months, she had no past history of any significant medical illness and was not on any regular medications. Her general physical and systemic examination was unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her management?

A 39-year-old female visits the endocrinologist with her routine lipid profile result. The doctor suspects the metabolic syndrome in the patient. Which of the following lipid profile results meets the criteria for this syndrome?

A 40-year-old female presents to the clinic with diffuse neck swelling for the last year, which is increasing in size. She is asked her to raise her arms above the head with elbows touching the ears. A couple of seconds later, her face turns red. What is this clinical sign known as?

A 40-year-old lady presented in the surgery clinic for follow-up after 6 weeks of thyroid surgery of hot nodule. She was presented with complaints of weight gain, cold intolerance, and bradycardia. On laboratory investigation, her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) was raised, however, T3 and T4 were found to be decreased in concentration. What is the most appropriate cause of symptoms in this patient?

A 40-year-old male ingested Kuchila seeds (Stridnine nux vomica) for sexual wellness considering it to be a herbal medicine. What side effects will he experience considering he ingested the whole seed with pericarp?

A 40-year-old male undergoes a successful coronary angioplasty. He is a known case of diabetes and is on insulin therapy. Which of these changes to his insulin therapy is most likely needed after the surgery?

answers.option: Same dose split in more time intervals

question: A 40-years old male presented to the clinic with the complaint of polyuria, and polydipsia. His lab revealed an HBa1C of 6.1%. What is the interpretation of the results?

A 42-year-old lady has had a history of lethargy, lack of energy, amenorrhea, and loss of libido for the last year. On examination, she looks pale, with wrinkled skin, and low blood pressure. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 42-year-old woman was incidentally detected to have a 2-cm left adrenal gland mass while she underwent computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen to investigate the cause of her pelvic pain and menstrual irregularities. Which one of the following is the most common cause of an incidentally detected adrenal mass?

A 44-year-old male, with no prior comorbidities, presents with body aches and fatigue. His lab results show: parathyroid hormone (PTH) = 103 pg/mL (10-65), Ca 9.0 mg/dl (8.5-10.0), PO4 = 3.0 mg/dl (2.5-5.0), albumin = 4.4 g/dL (2.5-5.5), alkaline phosphatase = 243 IU/L (< 125), and vitamin D = 8.0 ng/mL (> 30). What is the most probable cause?

A 45-year-old female presents with a nodule in her thyroid region. Orphan Annie's eye nuclei and invaginations of the nuclear membrane are visible on the microscope. Fine needle aspiration of the nodule material shows psammoma bodies within the cores of papillae. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with irregular menses for 5 months. She sometimes experiences heavy menstrual flow and consults her gynecologist for this. Her weight is increasing steadily over the past year and she becomes fatigued after minor house chores. Her gynecologist advised thyroid function tests and referred her to an endocrinologist for further management. On examination, her body mass index (BMI) is 29 kg/m2, and her blood pressure is 135/98 mmHg. Following are the lab results: thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH): 6.6 mIU/L (0.4-4.2), serum T4: 6.8 ng/ml (5.5-11.5), anti-thyroid peroxidase antibodies: 223 IU/L (<35). What is the biochemical interpretation of her lab results?

A 45-year-old woman reports a feeling of fullness in her neck without any other complaints. This enlargement has been gradual and painless for more than 1 year. Physical examination confirms diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland without any apparent masses. Laboratory studies of thyroid function show a normal free T4 level and a slightly increased TSH level. Imaging shows a solitary, spherical, encapsulated lesion that is demarcated from the surrounding thyroid parenchyma by a well-defined, intact capsule. What is the most likely cause of these findings?

A 46-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of increased appetite, nausea, headache, fatigue muscle weakness, and pain in the limbs. His laboratory results show serum calcium 2.92 mmol/L (2.10-2.65 mmmol/L), serum urea 5.9 mmol/L (3.6-6.6 mmol/L), and blood parathyroid hormone 97 pmol/L (15-62 pmol/L). What is the most probable diagnosis?
A 46-year-old man is newly diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He is advised to exercise regularly by his physician. Which of the following is not a beneficial effect of exercise in people with diabetes?

A 46-year-old woman presents with neck pain radiating to the jaw and fever following a recent episode of sore throat. She also complains of fatigue and excessive sweating. Which thyroid disorder is most likely?

A 47-year-old man exhibited signs and symptoms of acromegaly. Radiological studies indicate the presence of a large pituitary tumor. Surgical treatment of this disease is only partially effective in controlling the disease. At this point, which of the following drugs is most likely to be used as a pharmacological therapy?

A 48-year-old, white female complains of progressive weakness, lethargy, and cold intolerance. She also complains of weight gain, coarsening of facial features, hair loss, and increasing hoarseness of her voice. Laboratory results show low levels of T3 and T4 and high thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels. Which drug is the most appropriate?

A 49-year-old female experienced multiple attacks of abdominal pain last year. Three times she had passed stones in the urine during these episodes of pain. Now she is experiencing pain in her right middle finger for one month. On physical examination, her finger is tender. Laboratory reports show calcium 13.7 mg/ dL, phosphate 1.9 mg/ dL, and Creatinine 1.1mg/ dL, albumin 4.8 mg/ dL. Which of the following bone lesions is she most likely to have?

A 5-year girl presents to a rural dispensary in Pakistan with height and weight <2nd percentile and 3rd percentile, respectively. There is no significant family history. Clinical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following conditions is the most likely cause of short stature in this girl?

A 5-year-old girl presents to a rural dispensary and her height and weight are <2nd percentile and 3rd percentile respectively. There is no significant family history. Clinical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following conditions is most likely the cause of short stature in this girl?

A 50-year-old female presents with incidental finding of parathyroid adenoma on neck ultrasound. History and medical examination do not reveal any signs or symptoms however she insists on the removal of the adenoma. What criteria will justify parathyroidectomy in this patient?

answers.option: Decrease in serum calcium level of more than 5 mg/dl of upper normal limit

question: A 50-year-old male is planning to undergo a total parathyroidectomy for multiple gland diseases. He shows concerns over the life-long management of postoperative hypocalcemia. How would you reassure the patient?

answers.option: Counsel regarding auto-transplantation of 50 mg of parathyroid tissue in brachioradialis
Counsel to make him believe that this is inevitable complication
Counsel regarding easy availability of calcium supplements
Counsel to get second opinion on surgery

question: A 50-year-old man presented in the outpatient department with muscle weakness, weight loss, extreme fatigue, peptic ulcereration, hypercalcemia, mood disturbances, and pathological fracture of the femur. Clinicians suspect primary hyperparathyroidism as a cause of his illness, what is the best diagnostic test to confirm hyperparathyroidism in this patient?

A 54-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with a complaint of attacks of numbness on and off in her lower limbs. Her bone profile shows serum calcium 1.93 mmo/L (2.10-2.65 mmol/L), serum urea 4.2 mmol/L (3.6-6.6 mmol/L), serum phosphorus 2.56 mmol/L (1.75-1.9 mmol/L) and blood parathyroid hormone 12 pmol/L (15-62 pmol/L). What is she suffering from?

A 54-year-old female visits an endocrinologist with the complaint of not being able to notice the slipped-off slipper from the foot during walking until she looks at her feet. History suggests that she is a known case of diabetes for the past 10 years. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old female comes to the clinic with complaints of polyuria, polydipsia, and polyphagia. Laboratory investigations were done. What are the confirmed values that meet the diagnostic threshold for diabetes?

A 55-year-old otherwise healthy man feels a small lump on the left side of his neck. His physician palpates a firm, painless, 2 cm cervical lymph node. The thyroid gland is not palpable. A chest radiograph is unremarkable. Laboratory findings include calcium of 9.1 mg/ dL, phosphorus is 3.3 mg/dL, thyroxine of 8.7 micrograms, and TSH is 2.3 mU/L. Hemoglobin, blood cells, and platelet count are normal. Fine needle aspiration of the thyroid gland was done and the following structures appeared under a microscope, "The nuclei of cells contain finely dispersed chromatin, which imparts an optically clear or empty appearance, giving rise to the ground-glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei. In addition, invaginations of the cytoplasm give the appearance of intranuclear inclusions". What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?

A 55-years old woman with type 2 diabetes was going to start an oral antidiabetic drug that inhibits renal glucose reuptake from the filtrate, thus reducing blood glucose. Which of the following drugs can it be?

A 57-year-old lady presented in the outpatient department with a complaint of frequent semi-solid stools and palpitation. She lost 8kg weight in the past 6 months. On examination, she has had lumpy bumpy painless swelling in her neck for 20 years. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman comes to the clinic with complaints of tingling sensation in her fingertips, toes, and lips, accompanied by twitching of facial muscles. She also has muscle pains or cramps, particularly in her legs and feet. She also complains of mood changes and tiredness. Her skin has become increasingly dry and rough in the last five months. Laboratory tests reveal a low blood calcium level, low parathyroid hormone level, high blood phosphorus level, and a low blood magnesium level. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 57-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea and emotional disturbances. She has upper truncal obesity. Laboratory results show elevated serum levels of cortisol, which can be lowered by the administration of dexamethasone. Which of the following is the most likely cause of hypercortisolism in this patient?

A 6-month-old infant is brought to the outpatient department with by his parents with concerns about his general health. According to them, he was born at term at home with good weight and length but had a history of prolonged jaundice. Now they feel he is not active; he sleeps more and feeds less. There is also a history of constipation. On examination, the anterior fontanelle is open and large and the posterior fontanelle is still open. Which is the most likely investigation that will help in the diagnosis?

A 6-month-old infant presented in OPD with concerned parents about his general health. According to them he was born at term at home with good weight and length but had a history of prolonged jaundice. Now they feel he is inactive; he sleeps more and feeds less. There is also a history of constipation. On examination, the anterior fontanel is open and large and the posterior fontanel is still open. Which is the most likely investigation that will help in the diagnosis?

A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with complaints of gastric irritation, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain. He also complains of burning sensation in the urethra, pain in loins, and passing black-colored urine. What is the most probable cause for the above-mentioned symptoms?

A 6-year-old child is brought to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. He was previously healthy but has a history of easy fatigability, weight loss, and increased thirst. On examination, heart rate is 145 beats/min, respiratory rate is 50 breaths/min, and temperature is 98 F. Chest is clear on auscultation. On investigations, arterial blood gases (ABGs) show pH = 7.2, HCO3 = 12 mEq/L; while, random blood sugar level is 360 mg/dL. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 60-year-old male has increased blood pressure, heart rate, and signs of heart failure. He was diagnosed with a tumor involving the adrenal cortex. Which part of the adrenal cortex is probably involved?
A 60-year-old patient was diagnosed with a toxic thyroid adenoma. Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient?

A 60-year-old woman has felt a “lump” on the right side of her neck for several months. On physical examination, she has a firm 3 cm mass in the right lobe of the thyroid gland. There is no palpable lymphadenopathy. Laboratory studies show a serum TSH level of 3 mU/L and a T4 level of 8.8 µg/dL. A fine-needle aspiration biopsy is done, and she undergoes a thyroidectomy. A 3-cm solid mass is present within the right thyroid lobe. Six months later, she visited her physician again because of pain in the right thigh. A radiograph shows a fracture of the right femur in an area of lytic bone destruction. A radioiodine scan shows uptake localized to the region of the fracture. Which of the following was most likely to have been present in the patient's thyroid gland?

A 7-year-old boy picks a seed from the park and chewed and ingested it. He later develops extreme muscle contractions and convulsions. He gets diagnosed with strychnine poisoning. In terms of mechanism of action, which part of the spinal cord does strychnine stimulate?

A 7-year-old boy picks a seed from the park and chewed and ingested it. He later develops extreme muscle contractions and convulsions. He gets diagnosed with strychnine poisoning. Which of the following defects occurs in strychnine poisoning?

answers.option: It is characterized by loin pain
It affects the anterior horn of the spinal cord
It affects the posterior horn of the spinal cord

question: A 7-year-old boy, who is healthy and school-going, comes to the outpatient department accompanied by his parents, for the evaluation of short stature. He is usually lethargic and is not performing well in school. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 7-year-old boy, who is healthy and school-going, comes to the outpatient department accompanied by his parents, for the evaluation of short stature. His bone age is 5 years, and height age is 5 years. There are no dysmorphic features. Routine laboratory investigations are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next investigation?
A 72-year-old male patient was recently diagnosed with hyperparathyroidism. His calcium is 13.2 mg/dl. Which of the following other abnormality would be seen in this patient?

A 73-year-old woman has noticed a 10-kg weight loss in the past 3 months. She is becoming increasingly icteric and has constant vague epigastric pain, nausea, and episodes of bloating and diarrhea. There is mild tenderness to palpation in the upper abdomen, but bowel sounds are present. Her stool is negative for occult blood. Laboratory findings include a total serum bilirubin concentration of 11.6 mg/dL and a direct bilirubin level of 10.5 mg/dL. Which of the following conditions involving the pancreas is most likely to be present?

A 73-year-old woman has noticed a 10-kg weight loss in the past 3 months. She is becoming increasingly lethargic and has constant vague epigastric pain, nausea, and episodes of bloating and diarrhea. There is mild tenderness to palpation in the upper abdomen, but bowel sounds are present. Her stool is negative for occult blood. Laboratory findings include a total serum bilirubin concentration of 11.6 mg/dL and a direct bilirubin level of 10.6 mg/dL. Which of the following conditions involving the pancreas is most likely to be present?
A 9-month-old kid presents with a history of prolonged jaundice and umbilical hernia. What is the most likely etiology?

A 9-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician due to concerns about her growth. Her parents report that she has consistently been below the 3rd percentile for height, and they've noticed a lack of height gain compared to her classmates otherwise she is good in her studies. The girl's medical history is unremarkable, and she has not experienced any significant illnesses. On examination, her growth velocity is significantly below the expected range for her age, and her bone age is delayed for his height age. What is the most likely cause of the patient's short stature?
A 9-year-old kid presents with features suggestive of dwarfism. What is the most common cause of this condition?
A bronchoscopy of a patient reveals a lung small cell carcinoma. Which of the following would be raised in this patient?

A child presents to the emergency department with complaints of vomiting, seizures, and respiratory distress after having eaten a sausage. Upon physical examination, there is a descending symmetric flaccid paralysis of voluntary muscles and loss of deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following can be the cause of these symptoms?
A child suffers from growth hormone deficiency. Which of the following is the best indicator?
A class was shown a histological slide that had three distinct cell layers but all had abundant smooth endoplasmic reticulum. Which of the following organs could it be?

A couple brings their 12-year-old daughter to the clinic because she has not developed secondary sexual characters yet.
